title: Holmesdale Fanatics urge Crystal Palace fans to stick together to help club out of relegation mess
text:
Holmesdale Fanatics urge Crystal Palace fans to stick together to help club out of relegation mess Friday 24 February 2017 11:16 GMT Click to followES Sport Come on, lads: the Holmesdale Fanatics get behind Palace but many fans could not hide their fury during the Sunderland rout Getty Images 
Crystal Palace are back at Selhurst Park tomorrow for the first time since their crushing 4-0 defeat against Sunderland. 
Palace were booed off at half-time after they conceded three goals in three minutes at the end of the first half in that game and one furious fan ran onto the pitch to confront defender Damien Delaney as the mood turned ugly. 
Home supporters chanted “you’re not fit to wear the shirt” and the atmosphere was poisonous on an afternoon when Palace folded. 
Palace players might fear a backlash from home fans when they play Middlesbrough tomorrow but a key group of Eagles supporters say it is important everyone is behind the team for what is a huge relegation clash at the bottom of the Premier League. Crystal Palace vs Middlesbrough: Premier League preview 
“The Palace fanbase will be doing what it does best and creating a strong, unified front,” say the Holmesdale Fanatics. “We have stood together and made it count at Play-off Finals, facing liquidation, relegation and coming from three goals down against Liverpool [2013-14 season] — that is what Palace are famed for and, as a club, these are our strengths. 
“This season will go down to the wire and these games are now do or die. The players know what must be done and they will have support from the stands in doing it. 
“We can restore the unity and spirit which has defined the Palace way that has made us so successful these last few years. In the players and supporters working together and uniting the club, we have the power to climb out of this situation. Tomorrow can be a turning point.” 
Palace chairman Steve Parish went into the home dressing room after the Sunderland defeat to speak to the players and get across the sense of frustration among fans. Crystal Palace's Premier League run-in Crystal Palace's Premier League run-in 1/14 
Where will Sam Allardyce's side pick up points as they bid to beat the drop? Getty Images Liverpool FC via Getty Images 11/14 Burnley (H) 
Reverse fixture: Crystal Palace 1 Manchester United 2 AFP/Getty Images 
The relationship between Palace supporters and the team has seemingly fractured in recent months but, with Palace in real danger of going down, the Holmesdale Fanatics feel it is important for the club to show unity on and off the pitch in the battle for survival. 
“We have a unique identity which should be proud to stand apart and take on the rest of the Premier League,” they insist. “All of us at the club from the supporters to the players and to the owners need to remember what brought us here, now is the time to recapture that spirit. 
“Since 2010 and administration, our strength as a club had come from the unity of players, supporters and owners all embracing a unique, proud south London mentality which created a culture of togetherness powering us from the bottom of the Championship to the top six of the Premier League. 
“Leaders on the pitch giving 100 per cent for the shirt, backed by passionate unending support in the stands, fans united by a feeling of a defiant, underdog, never-say-die Palace spirit.” Read more Hennessey: Palace players believe we can turn things around 
The Holmesdale Fanatics feel Palace have suffered because of a move away from that spirit. 
“The blueprint embraced the local south London identity, understood the importance of local players playing for their local club as well as having people involved in the set-up, both on and off the pitch, that have a bond with the club and the fanbase,” they add. 
“This continuity is what made us so successful. This season by seemingly moving away from this blueprint in such a short space of time and embracing aspects of the corporate side of the Premier League we have lost what made us unique as a club and have eroded that fighting spirit which had made us strong.” 
Selhurst Park is seen by many as having one of the best atmospheres in the Premier League but Palace have the worst home record in the top flight this season. 
They have won just twice at home and lost nine of their 12 matches. 
“The reaction to the Sunderland performance came from over a years’ worth of frustrations in the Premier League,” say the Holmesdale Fanatics. 
“If we can do our bit to restore this spirit, we can make Selhurst the intimidating place that it used to be and recapture our home form.” More about:
